Internal Restrictions:
*Moving around in Slovenia: Movement between all statistical regions is permitted.
*Public spaces and further measures: A surgical mask or FFP2 type mask must be worn in all enclosed public spaces, on public transport, in open places and outside where a distance of 1.5 metres cannot be maintained and in private vehicles when travelling with members of other households for work purposes.
Fabric masks are no longer permitted.
Face masks are not compulsory for children under the age of six, primary school pupils up to 5th grade when in classrooms, and people practicing non-contact sports, if a distance of 3 metres can be maintained.
Many of the rules apply across all of Slovenia, but some rules are specific to regions depending on their Covid-rating. You can find the status of a specific statistical region on the Slovenian Government website. Unless stated elsewhere, the rules below apply to all of Slovenia. Further details can be found on the Slovene government website. • People aged 12 and above will need to demonstrate their COVID-19 status through the Slovene “PCT” in order to access services and venues. This includes leisure facilities (shops, bars, restaurants, hotels, museums and libraries), public transport, public sports events, religious gatherings and public cultural events.
• The Slovene PCT can be demonstrated by showing a valid identity document and one of the following three criteria: 1. A full vaccination certificate (from 1 February, over 18s will need to show that their second COVID-19 vaccination was received no more than 270 days previously). OR proof of a Moderna or Pfizer booster shot, which is not subject to the 270 day limit;
2. A negative PCR test taken within the last 72 hours or antigen result from a test taken within the last 48 hours;
3. A document (dated more than 10 days ago and less than six months ago) proving you have recently recovered from COVID. • You should expect to be asked to show evidence that you meet one of these requirements, together with a valid identity document.
• The only exceptions to this requirement are: emergency departments in hospitals; COVID testing and COVID and flu vaccine centres; grocery stores and pharmacies that are not located inside shopping malls; and charities providing urgent support. In grocery stores and pharmacies you should expect social distancing measures of 10 square metres per customer to be in place, and a sign at the entrance showing the maximum number of people that are allowed inside.
• Slovenia will accept the proof of COVID-19 recovery and vaccination record and proof of COVID-19 vaccination issued in the Crown Dependencies. From 1 February 2022, people aged 18 and above, will need to show proof that their second COVID-19 vaccination was received no more than 270 days previously. Vaccination certificates issued after a booster dose of Moderna or Pfizer will also be considered as proof of vaccination and is not subject to the 270 day limit. Your appointment card from vaccination centres is not designed to be used as proof of vaccination and should not be used to demonstrate your vaccine status.
If you hold a Slovenian health card, rapid antigen tests are available free of charge at test centres. If you do not hold a Slovenian health card, you should expect to pay for a test. See the list of test centres. • Restaurants and bars are open between 5am and 10pm, and are only allowed to provide a seated service (indoors or outdoors). Takeaway services are permitted. People aged 12 and above will need to demonstrate their COVID-19 status through the Slovene “PCT” (as above).
• Nightclubs, bars and restaurants that offer entertainment (music or dance) are not allowed to open
• Hotels are allowed to open. People aged 12 and above will need to demonstrate their COVID-19 status through the Slovene “PCT” (as above).
• Public sports events are allowed where fixed seating is provided and where every other seat can be left vacant. The use of surgical or FFP2 face mask is mandatory. People aged 12 and above will need to demonstrate their COVID-19 status through the Slovene “PCT” (as above).
• All education establishments continue to deliver classes in person. Schools will conduct rapid antigen self-testing on all students three times a week
• Indoor and outdoor sports facilities are open. People aged 12 and above will need to demonstrate their COVID-19 status through the Slovene “PCT” (as above).
• Visits to care homes and hospitals are by appointment only. You should contact the care home or hospital you wish to visit for full details of visiting options, noting that these options are subject to short notice change.
• All services within Slovenian public administration offices are by appointment only
• You should not attend hospitals or dental clinics for non-essential reasons, unless you have an appointment.
• Libraries, museums and galleries are open. Indoor culture facilities are allowed to operate up to a limited capacity, which will be displayed at the entrance. The use of surgical or FFP2 face mask is mandatory. People aged 12 and above will need to demonstrate their COVID-19 status through the Slovene “PCT” (as above).
• Social gatherings are not permitted, except between members of the same household or immediate family members.
• Religious gatherings are allowed where a distance of 1.5 metres can be observed between people. The use of surgical or FFP2 face mask is mandatory. People aged 12 and above will need to demonstrate their COVID-19 status through the Slovene “PCT” (as above).
• Public cultural events in open public spaces are not allowed, but are permitted in enclosed public spaces with fixed seating, where every other seat can be left vacant. The use of surgical or FFP2 face mask is mandatory. People aged 12 and above will need to demonstrate their COVID-19 status through the Slovene “PCT” (as above).
The Slovene government provides English-language coronavirus guidance and updates.
